slides.title: Introduction to PolicyCenter Modifiers
slides.notes: Introduction to the concept of modifiers in Guidewire PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to our exploration of modifiers in Guidewire PolicyCenter. Modifiers are powerful tools that allow us to adjust premiums based on specific criteria. They play a crucial role in tailoring insurance products to meet diverse needs. As we dive into this lesson, we'll uncover how modifiers interact with the data model and how they can be customized to fine-tune rating calculations.

slides.title: Understanding Modifiers
slides.notes: Modifiers are crucial in the rating process, affecting how premiums are calculated.
slides.narration: Modifiers in PolicyCenter are integral to the rating process, allowing for nuanced control over premium calculations. They're designed to apply adjustments based on factors like risk or customer characteristics. Understanding how they fit into the data model and how they can be configured is essential for customizing insurance products effectively.

slides.title: Modifier Application Levels
slides.notes: Modifiers can be applied at different levels: product and policy line.
slides.narration: Modifiers can be applied at different levels within PolicyCenter—either at the product level or the policy line level. Product-level modifiers, such as those in commercial packages, affect all lines within a product. In contrast, policy line modifiers target specific lines, offering granular control for specialized adjustments.

slides.title: Rate Modifier
slides.originalNotes:
Rate modifier
Modifiers added to the product affect rating for all lines in that product. Modifiers added to a policy line affect only that line. They are called ProductModifier patterns.

One example in the base configuration of modifiers are those on the General Liability policy line within Commercial Package product.

slides.title: Modifier Pattern: ProductModifiers
slides.originalNotes:
Modifier pattern
Product-level modifiers are called ProductModifiers. They are applied to product only for multi- line policies such as CPP (Commercial Package). They apply to all policy lines on apolicy. An example is the •CPPIRPM" (Commercial Package Policy Individual Risk Premium Modification) which affects rating of coverages for all lines within CPP.

CPPIRPM: (CPP Individual Risk Premium Modification) This is a specific example of a scheduled rate modifier. It is used primarily in property and liability polices. The rating and quoting engine takes factors into account in determining the premium. These factors can include things like the size of premium, spread of risk, superior building construction, and the quality of management.

slides.title: Schedule Rate Modifiers
slides.originalNotes:
Schedule rate modifier
The schedule rate modifier is a specific type of modifier that provides credits or debits within established value ranges. Use them for factors such as management, property, and other intangibles that you cannot quantify as part of the submission.

slides.narration: Schedule rate modifiers are versatile, providing credits or debits based on predefined criteria. They're ideal for adjusting rates based on intangible factors like management quality. This flexibility allows insurers to reflect nuanced risk assessments in their pricing, an essential feature for competitive product offerings.

slides.title: RateFactor Typelist
slides.originalNotes:
RateFactor typelist
A rating input modifier consists of one or more rate factors. Rate factors must be listed in the RateFactorType typelist before they can be added to a schedule rate.

The first step in creating a schedule rate modifier is to create any needed rate factor in the RateFactorType.

Configuration tip: Studio automatically knows about new typecodes, so configuration users can create the schedule rate modifier without restarting the server. However, because changes to typelists are considered data model changes, configuration users must restart the server before they can test the schedule rate modifier in the user Interface.

slides.title: Modifier Impact on Rating
slides.notes: How modifiers influence the final premium calculation.
slides.narration: The impact of modifiers on rating is profound, altering premiums by applying specific adjustments. Their configuration determines how various factors influence the final premium. By understanding this impact, developers can ensure that policies are priced accurately and reflect the underlying risk.

questionData.question:
For the Personal Auto policy line, why are there two possible values for a
modifier’s "modifier type"?
questionData.answer:
In Personal Auto, a modifier can be associated with the policy line or to a specific
vehicle. When creating the modifier, you specify a modifier type to denote if it is policy
line level (PAModifier) or vehicle level (PAVehicleModifier).

slides.notes: How modifiers work with the rating engine to calculate premiums.
slides.narration: Modifiers are intricately linked to the rating engine, which processes their inputs to calculate premiums. This integration ensures that all adjustments are accurately reflected in the final price. Understanding this interaction is key to developing robust rating solutions that meet client needs.

questionData.question: When do you need to add values to the RateFactorType typelist?
questionData.answer: You need to add typecodes to the RateFactorType typelist when you create a schedule rate modifier and the desired rate factors don't already exist.
